+Liel M. I am a 24 year old Irish Catholic, but honestly I'm not very 
religious. Nonetheless, I know what is immoral, and I know that IDF forces 
invaded Palestinian territory. I know that Israel has the support of 
"Murica", and we all know the Americans went a tiny bit power hungry and 
militaristic(at one point they prided themselves on being neutral and 
staying out of the affairs of other countries) after nuking two Japanese 
cities...killing civilians. It doesn't take a genius to notice how fucked 
up things are, the fact that the UN is dominated by the most powerful, not 
the most just. I have no problem with Jews, I have a problem with unjust 
aggression. I have no problems with Muslims, I have a problem with 
jihadists. If ever invasions aren't justified, if ever power isn't 
worshipped, if ever an international peacekeeping organisation(the UN) 
isn't dominated by MILITARY POWERS and is instead dominated by neutral and 
diplomatic powers, then I will be happy. Then I will not have hatred in my 
heart. We live in a world where, as far as my research has shown me, people 
are detained in psych wards and blacklisted for questioning world events. 
We live in a world where people who damage the industrial equipment of 
people destroying nature are called "Eco-Terrorists", we live in a world 
where the people that invaded Palestine to establish the Israeli 
Nation-State are recognized and justified by the most powerful countries in 
the world. What we have, dear, is a world where power sets the rules, 
rather than moral actions. That is what I hate, and everything I'm saying 
has been brought up before. Yes, Palestinians have done horrible things, 
but you need to ask yourself: who started it all? Who invaded who? Who 
instigated the conflict? If soldiers enter a territory out of nowhere, and 
start annexing that territory, the people will fight back. That will start 
war. Both sides will commit atrocities, but the fault is with the side that 
invaded and started annexing the territory in the first place. Israel was 
established by people from around the world, people that decided to gather 
there and form a homeland. That homeland, you cannot deny unless your 
history textbooks are censored/altered for propaganda, that it was the 
founders of the Israeli Nation-State that occupied what was at one point 
Palestinian territory. This conversation is over. I guess I do not know you 
personally, so, for being rude to you and declaring hatred, I feel bad. You 
seem like a nice person. Still, I hate what Israeli forces have done 
because of my personal belief that it is always the aggressor in warfare 
that is in the wrong, and not the defending forces. I believe that the only 
role of a military force, should be to defend a people from external 
threats, the same way police keep internal affairs in order. Aggressive 
warfare is by it's very nature, fascist and imperialistic. I would have had 
a DIFFERENT way for Jewish diaspora to have a united identity: something 
along the lines of the Order of Malta. The idea of Israel should be in the 
hearts of the Jewish diaspora, it should not be a militaristic, land 
holding country. Biblical scripture itself says that the people of Israel 
are a "peaceful people" who are "without walls." This description and the 
Nation-State of Israel seem to contradict one another. The materialistic, 
politico-military country of Israel, seems very warlike. The fact remains 
that the IDF is an occupying force, and Arabs have limited rights. 
Palestinian children are being bullied and beaten up on the way to school. 
Do you think it is right for a grown man to harm a child? I am a strong man 
at 24. A broad, hard chest and muscled arms. Would it be right for me to 
strike or intimidate a child with my adult build? No, it would not be 
right. I have no problem with Jewish people having equal rights, but I 
believe that equal rights should be a human right, something universal as 
long as an individual has done no harm. The only warfare I agree with is 
defensive warfare. I believe that attacking people should always be a last 
resort, because violence is not necessary, despite the human insistence on 
violence to solve problems. I want a world where violence and power do not 
rule. I want a world where diplomacy and logic take priority. I want a 
world where no people are imposed on by an external force. The people of 
Palestine should have their rights respected, and have the right to not 
live in fear. The same I will say for the Jewish diaspora. I identify, as 
an Irishman, both with Jews and the people of Palestine. My people were 
oppressed for being Catholic, by British Protestants. Do to Britain's 
geopolitical position, the nations of Europe could not risk allying with my 
people, because it was Britain that was more convenient in terms of trade 
and alliances given it's proximity to continental Europe. My ancestors 
could not get jobs to pay for food because it was illegal to hire 
Catholics. My people faced the same persecution that Jews experienced just 
for being Jews. And currently, Palestinians are facing the same 
persecution, for being Arabs, and your nation of Israel is in power. Does 
that now justify the people who oppressed my ancestors and your ancestors? 
Is power, having your boot in another's face, all that matters? Is power 
the arbiter of a particular era's justice? That is for you to decide.

ago. Both Israel and the Palestinians have legitimate claims and concerns, 
and if anyone can't see that they're a little out of touch with reality.

After WW2 Palestine was divided by Britain (who took control after the 
collapse of the Ottoman Empire) and the UN into two areas to accommodate 
the influx of Jewish refugees after two-thirds of them were slaughtered by 
the Nazis in Europe. One area was for Palestinians, and one for Jews. When 
the British mandate for Palestine expired in 1948, the Jewish area declared 
independence and, no longer under British protection, all of its Arab 
neighbours invaded the next day. Israel eventually won that war and 
solidified its position in later wars. The Palestinians have been caught in 
the crossfire ever since, and their position has worsened since being 
gradually abandoned by Jordan beginning in the 1970s. 

Both groups have had it rough, and both have a claim to the land. They both 
need to stop fighting and acknowledge the legitimacy of the other's claims.﻿

Well, this is a depressing cross-section of my country. I dont know if the 
majority of Canadians are actually so ill-informed, or if the interviewer 
just had bad luck, but damn. If this survey were conducted in 1875, 
Canadians would say something like "Well, I side with the Americans because 
I have heard that the USA is a country, and I dont know anything about the 
Lakota".

That said, the question is far two simplistic. It does imply that there are 
2 solitary sides to this conflict (and the word "conflict" here is also 
contentious), and both are unified. Israel, as a state, can be judged in a 
solitary view (but not the Israeli citizens), and Palestine is more 
complex. Neither "side" is a monolith that wants one thing. Both sides have 
religious fanatics and both sides have people who genuinely want a just 
peace.
That said, Israel as a generalized camp is in the wrong, and the groups 
within Israel that truly advocate a just peace are becoming a disturbingly 
small minority, many of them are just quitting Israel all together, which 
gives North America an interesting little trade: We get the best and most 
sane Israeli's and in exchange, Israel gets the most insane rightist North 
American Jews. Which is good for Canada, as it is less Harper votes, but 
really bad for Palestinians, as it means more insane settlers.
Bottom line, Israeli's and Palestinians are capable of finding peace with 
eachother. Zionism as an ideology does not readily allow for this. The 
ideology that puts more and more illegal settlements in the west bank is 
the primary cause of conflict. Palestinians were (and may still be) willing 
to accept peace along the green line (which would be a negotiated surrender 
from their historical point of view.), but the Zionist ideology is all to 
content to keep hammering in the nails of the 2 state solutions coffin.﻿

In summary, most Canadians know next-to-nothing about the issue.

Though I know a fair bit about the issue and would probably have as much 
trouble answering. That`s because I side with my values rather than with 
one particular side, and both sides are out of alignment with my values in 
different ways and at different times.

Plus there are a lot of invisible elements of the conflict that most people 
never think about. Natural resources play a lot bigger role in the conflict 
than most people realize, which will probably become more apparent in the 
coming years. A lot of the strike-counterstrike violence we see now is a 
longer term play by either side to assert their claims to resources. The 
peace process slowed to a grind when oil was discovered off-shore, and it 
completely imploded when oil was discovered under the Westbank. Both sides 
have an interest in avoiding a settlement at the moment. Compromising on x 
or y scrap of semi-desert is one thing, but compromising on a scrap of 
semi-desert potentially worth billions of dollars is another.﻿
